intro: Amomum lophophorum, commonly known as the mountain cardamom, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the ginger family (Zingiberaceae) and is characterized by its aromatic, finger-like rhizomes that are used in traditional medicine and culinary applications. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, featuring broad, elliptical leaves and small, pale green flowers that develop into dark purple berries. Its essential oils, rich in compounds like cineole and limonene, contribute to its medicinal properties and distinctive fragrance.
